slides.text: _Hai. The name's Botty. They're lazy, so I'm the one doing this presentation._

_Fine, I'll start._ 
          Looking back at the Project Proposal in Lab 2...

Scope changes: Nothing taken out of 'Critical' priority, only out of 'Nice to Have' priority. 
          So the project was technically within the anticipated scope. _(Or so they say.)_

Some changes were time-frame related, but others were merely user-experience related. 
          For an example of the latter: 
                    No leaderboard: Originally meant to appear after every turn, but now only available after typing in a command
Also, no white card images: Originally meant to be distributed like black cards, but ten of them would clutter the screen.

Due to time-frame, these features also got the boot: 
          A website: 
                    - Would've had instructions on how to install Telegram and play the game 
                    - Information and introductions for the development team 
                    - A development blog of current and future development issues and projects regarding the game 
                    - An option to contact the development team, to report bugs or request features

A database: 
          - Used JSON files for cards instead, as they were already online 
          _(Lazy.)_

User ability to choose card packs: 
          - Would've been able to choose from preloaded card packs when setting up the lobby 
          - Would've been able to turn off specific card packs or cards

A child-friendly version: 
          - Removal of more mature cards 
          _(Good riddance. This isn't Apples to Apples.)_

A global player management system: 
          - Would've allowed creating, finding, and joining public games, along with matchmaking for players
_(Seriously, how many more do you have?)_

Custom keyboard: 
          - Used in-line buttons instead 
          - In-line is easier to navigate, as users don't have to scroll through 10 options on a keyboard
And that's it for scope changes.
_(Thank god)_

_And how did they get my wonderful self into existence, on-time and on-objective?_ 
          _Glad you asked._

Why our project met its stated objectives: 
          - We had experienced people on our team (read: Amir) who accurately estimated a feasible time and scope of the project from the beginning 
          - We were realistic with what was possible in the time frame 
          - Team members' familiarity with Java and Telegram

Why, continued: 
          - The development team used abstract and interface classes through Java so each member could complete their tasks without having to wait on each other 
          - I.e. Parallel development and deployment

Why, continued: 
          - There were already JSON files of card packs available online 
          - (Could've had to limit project scope if we had to manually insert our own card packs)

_And what lessons did you learn, now? 
          (Besides how to get a bot to do your presentation for you...) _

Lessons learned: 
          - Donâ€™t use two different API libraries and try to merge them together 
          _Yeah, Balaji_

Lessons, continued: 
          - Couldn't create a game in the group chat due to private messages (individual white card options) 
          - Had to create a lobby instead

Lessons, continued: 
          - Learned to discuss deadlines and setbacks honestly with group members 
          - If someone was behind, they admitted it and other members helped catch them up

Lessons, continued: 
          - Race conditions can wreak havoc on your logic

Lessons, continued: 
          - Project deployment  
          - Auto-deployment is required when you have one platform with multiple developers
_And now, what you've been waiting for._
_Let's play a game._
